sub_topic: Finding the inverse of a matrix
message_1:
Find the inverse of the following 2x2 matrix:
$$\begin{bmatrix}
1 & 2 \\
3 & 4 \\
\end{bmatrix}$$
message_2:
To find the inverse of a 2x2 matrix, we can use the following formula:

$$A^{-1} = \frac{1}{\text{det}(A)} \begin{bmatrix}
d & -b \\
-c & a \\
\end{bmatrix}$$

where A is the given matrix:

$$A = \begin{bmatrix}
a & b \\
c & d \\
\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}
1 & 2 \\
3 & 4 \\
\end{bmatrix}$$

First, we need to find the determinant of A:

$$\text{det}(A) = ad - bc = (1)(4) - (2)(3) = 4 - 6 = -2$$

Now, we can find the inverse of A using the formula:

$$A^{-1} = \frac{1}{\text{det}(A)} \begin{bmatrix}
d & -b \\
-c & a \\
\end{bmatrix} = \frac{1}{-2} \begin{bmatrix}
4 & -2 \\
-3 & 1 \\
\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}
-2 & 1 \\
1.5 & -0.5 \\
\end{bmatrix}$$

So, the inverse of the given matrix is:

$$A^{-1} = \begin{bmatrix}
-2 & 1 \\
1.5 & -0.5 \\
\end{bmatrix}$$
